speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 466, 590, 485]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[426, 572, 621, 591]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 606, 556, 625]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 641, 571, 660]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 675, 532, 710]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 875, 245]]<|/det|>

<label>Fig. 3.1b</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 516, 875, 551]]<|/det|>
The tube is displaced vertically and then released. The tube oscillates vertically in the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 548, 625, 567]]<|/det|>
At one time, the displacement is \(x\), as shown in Fig. 3.1b.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 579, 774, 598]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 603, 551, 631]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\frac{A\rho g}{m} x.\]

A charged particle of mass \(m\) and charge \(+q\) is travelling with velocity \(v\) in a vacuum. It enters a region of uniform magnetic field of flux density \(B\), as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 567, 181, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 567, 744, 586]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 118, 311, 137]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 241, 351, 260]]<|/det|>
alternating current.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 677, 92]]<|/det|> State what is meant by the acoustic impedance \(Z\) of a medium. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 945, 112]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 133, 876, 151]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 561, 183]]<|/det|> Two media have acoustic impedances \(Z_{1}\) and \(Z_{2}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 178, 875, 214]]<|/det|> The intensity reflection coefficient \(\alpha\) for the boundary between the two media is given by <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 215, 561, 255]]<|/det|> \[\alpha = \frac{(Z_2 - Z_1)^2}{(Z_2 + Z_1)^2}.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 875, 306]]<|/det|> Describe the effect on the transmission of ultrasound through a boundary where there is a large difference between the acoustic impedances of the two media. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 412, 875, 431]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 144, 463]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 875, 477]]<|/det|> Data for the acoustic impedance \(Z\) and the absorption coefficient \(\mu\) for fat and for muscle are shown in Fig. 10.1. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 490, 692, 600]]<|/det|>
\(Z/\mathrm {kg}\mathrm {m}^{-2}\mathrm {\sim s}^{-1}\)\(\mu /\mathrm {m}^{-1}\)
fat\(1.3\times 10^{6}\)48
muscle\(1.7\times 10^{6}\)23
